content.description: Climb sidepulls and thin ledges to a horizontal rail about 3/4 up.  From here, the crux requires a left gaston on a small crystal and some balance.  Exit up and right.
content.protection: pads and a spotter.  sandy landing but with a few yucca nearby.
content.location: From the Hall of Horrors parking lot, take the trail along the right side of the formations. You will pass the two main formations (East Wall, then West Wall). A larger section of desert separates the West Wall from King Dome. Cross this and head to the NE corner of Kingdome. There is one, very large boulder located on this corner. LHMFP is the only climb located on the SW face (other climbs are located on the NW, and NE faces).

content.description:
This testy problem features technical liebacking over a bulge to gain a crack and better holds - once established on the slab above it's easy to the top.

This problem may favor taller climbers slightly as they'll be able to reach the better holds straight away - either way you'll have to pull on a sharp lip of the crack for a move.
content.location: Located on the narrow west face of the boulder.

content.description:
Located on the north face of the boulder a short ways right of

Easy Flake

(5.7 R) which is identifiable as a right-slanting flake system.

Start matched from an edge (jump to reach if short), run your feet up and make a reach up and left to a good edge to join

Easy Flake

. From here you have three options - reverse your moves, jump off, or top out the problem by continuing out right to the west face and paddle up smears to the top.

Located right of

Death Spiral

on the north face and identifiable as a right-slanting flake system.

A quick pull (5.7) gains the flake which is traversed up and right to a ledge of sorts. From here you have three options - reverse your moves, jump off, or top out the problem by continuing out right to the west face and paddle up smears to the top (scary if climbing at the grade).

Located on the north face of the boulder at a scooped out area that's about 15' left of

Easy Flake

(5.7 R), the obvious right-slanting flake system.

Thin, technical edge climbing up a vertical face gain a "lip" of sorts at about 15' where the angle kicks back but the holds don't really get any better. Finish by heading either up and left or right, but beware the direct with it's hollow flakes and creaky edges.
